subject: Re: [junit] What's wrong with using inner classes for tests?

messageBody:
IMO; the "correct" answer totally depends on _why_ you're writing a
given test.

In the most general sense, you're writing a test to verify "something".
Your "something" is defined by some sort of boundary. Typical(/useful)
test boundaries in java are usually a single class, a package, a
subsystem, etc...

If your test wants an:
external view of "something"
#1 is strongest (only get to interact w/ public members)
#2 workable/convenient, but allows package visibility
internal view of "something"
#3 is typical/easiest

As for concerns that one path or another is a dead-end... I've used all
three-- none have killed or otherwise crippled my projects. I've
developed a strong preference for tests with maximum external views,
but don't hesitate to write white-box (#3) tests when something makes
me nervous.

-- Levi


On Wednesday, April 9, 2003, at 09:33 AM, Sandy McArthur wrote:

> Searching the message archive there seems to be three common places to
> put your tests.
>
> 1) Next to the class you are testing but in the same directory.
> 2) Next to the class you are testing but in a different directory.
> 3) In a public static inner class.
